yoruba: Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn.
gold: Whether one speaks twenty times or speaks thirty times, “I do not like it, and I will not accept it” is how the imbecile ends the discussion.
gen: The Yoruba proverb "Ká wí ogún, ká wí ọgbọ̀n, “Ng ò fẹ́, ng ò gbà” laṣiwèré fi ńpẹ̀kun ọ̀ràn" translates to English as: "After discussing strategies and wisdom, it is 'I don't want, I won't accept' that a fool uses to end a matter." This proverb suggests that a foolish person often dismisses wise counsel or solutions, choosing instead to reject them outright.
